long.para: qfft2ds(X, A) computes a two-sided Quaternion Fast Fourier Transform of the quaternion matrix X using transform axis pair A (direction in 3-space).

The transform axis pair, A must be a cell array of two elements which are pure quaternions (real or complex). They need not have unit modulus (although the transform itself is computed using a unit-modulus axis, so that the axis is a root of -1).

The transform computed by this function is a slight generalization of that of Ell (1992)., which had fixed transform axes of j and k for the left and right exponentials. The related function fft2ds provides the default axes of Ell's original transform.

This function is computed by fast Fourier transforms. The related function qdft2ds computes the same result by a much slower discrete Fourier transform. It is provided for test and verification purposes (the result is less accurate than the fast transform code, but it should differ by only small multiples of the machine rounding).

The inverse function is iqfft2ds and it has the same calling profile. It differs however, in applying a scale factor of 1/N where N is the number of elements in the array X (the product of the number of rows and the number of columns).
